channel.title: Just downloaded Ubuntu, trouble with .sh files
channel.description:
I am trying to make a .sh file to run a small java project I've made. Here is what I have:
[code] #!/bin/sh
java Engine.java
[/code]
What do I need to make it run? When I try to open it, nothing happens.
[size=3pt]dun make fun[/size]

item.title: Just downloaded Ubuntu, trouble with .sh files
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

In terminal:

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install openjdk-6-jdk
cd /path/to/class
java package/name/Engine

Edit: Looks like the problem was solved already.

Read full topic

@davidi2 wrote:

I’m guessing ‘Engine’ may be part of a package, in which case you need to do Full/Package/Name/Engine ARGS

item.title: Just downloaded Ubuntu, trouble with .sh files
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

His problem was already solved He needed to update his sources and then update packages.

And yea, I know, I was just saying that I didn’t have to set them; which eliminated one problem

Read full topic
item.source: Just downloaded Ubuntu, trouble with .sh files

item.title: Just downloaded Ubuntu, trouble with .sh files
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

[quote=“n10si t, post:7, topic:385600”][code]
sudo apt-get install sun-java6-jdk
Reading package lists… Done
Building dependency tree
Reading state information… Done
Package sun-java6-jdk is not available, but is referred to by another package.
This may mean that the package is missing, has been obsoleted, or
is only available from another source

E: Package ‘sun-java6-jdk’ has no installation candidate

[/code][/quote]

Try installing openjdk-6-jre and openjdk-6-jdk. Those are in the default repositories and OpenJDK is virtually the same as Sun Java.

[quote=“Davidi2, post:4, topic:385600”]Have you ever tried just ‘javac’, besides the direct path?

I’ve never had to set environmental variables with Linux[/quote]

Environment variables, not environmental. Also, the reason you haven’t had to set them is that application’s executables such as java, javac, javaw, javaws, etc will get installed in /usr/bin by the package manager which by default is already on your PATH.

@OP: you need to compile and then run your program. Compiling can be done like this:

javac ClassName.java

and then the class can be executed like so:

java ClassName

I would recommend using a build tool such as Apache Ant to simplify the process.

Read full topic

@davidi2 wrote:

Oh, you need to do this:

deb http://us.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ hardy multiverse deb-src http://us.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ hardy multiverse deb http://us.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ hardy-updates multiverse deb-src http://us.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ hardy-updates multiverse

Then try

item.title: Just downloaded Ubuntu, trouble with .sh files
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“n10si t, post:1, topic:385600”]I am trying to make a .sh file to run a small java project I’ve made. Here is what I have:

#!/bin/sh

java Engine.java

What do I need to make it run? When I try to open it, nothing happens.

[size=3pt]dun make fun[/size][/quote]
Navigate to the folder its in, in the terminal. Then you would (for example, run.sh) start the sh file by doing:
sh run.sh
As a command.

Read full topic
